en.value: Talking about habits and routines - Adverbial phrases of place, time and frequency
I have three coffees a day
Let's have a look in this unit at how we can describe some of our habits and routines.
I set my alarm for 7 a.m. on weekdays.
I catch up with my boss once a week.
We put the children to bed at 8 p.m.
How many times a day do you have a shower?
"Shower" can also be a verb. In some cases it's more common to say "to shower" instead of "to have a shower", especially when we're talking about how often we do it.
When did you last have a shower?
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Select the words in the correct order.
I set my alarm for 7 a.m. on weekdays.
Did you watch the news last night?

If we haven't had time to do something lately, like watching the news, we can say we need to "catch up on the news" to learn about recent events. We can also "catch up on something" else, like reading or working, to explain that we need to carry on doing something we haven't finished yet. We can also "catch up with someone" if we haven't seen them in a while, to find out what they have been doing lately.
He reads the newspaper on Sundays to catch up on the news.
I need to catch up on work.
I catch up with my boss once a week.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
to put the children to bed
We put the children to bed at 8pm.
to take the kids to school
My husband takes the kids to school.
What do Alice and her husband do?
They put the children to bed at 8 p.m.
They take the children to school at 8 a.m.
They set an alarm for 8 p.m.
My husband [k]takes[/k] the kids to school.
I normally have three coffees a day.
Do you make your lunch the night before?
My sister walks the dog every day.
We can also say "to take the dog for a walk" instead, with the same meaning. Let's have a look at the following examples:
I walk the dog three times a day.
Who wants to take the dog for a walk?
He makes lunch for his family.
He makes dinner for his friends.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Here’s a quick recap of all the words and expressions we’ve learned.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Did you [k]watch[/k] the news last night?
No, I didn't. I usually read the newspaper on Sundays to [k]catch up on[/k] the news. I went to bed at 10 p.m. last night. I was very tired.
Yes, but I get up early. I normally [k]set[/k] the alarm for 6 a.m., and then I take the dog for a walk.
My husband always [k]walks[/k] the dog. I [k]make[/k] breakfast and then we take the children to school.
I don't eat breakfast because I never have time. I only [k]have[/k] a coffee in the morning.
Do you take your lunch to work?
Yes, I always make my lunch the night before.
You're so organised! Well, I'd better go. I'll [k]catch up with[/k] you later.
Geoff watches the news on Sundays.
Geoff usually reads the newspaper on Sundays to catch up with the news.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
I [k]make breakfast[/k] for my family every morning.
Who takes the dog for a walk?
Geoff always [k]makes his lunch|makes lunch[/k] the night before.
Fill in the gap using the image.
I [k]walk the dog|take the dog for a walk[/k] in the mornings.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
I always [k]s[/k][k]e[/k][k]t[/k] an a[k]l[/k][k]a[/k][k]r[/k]m for 7 a.m.
What do Lucy and her husband do together in the morning?
I'd better go. I'll [k]catch up with[/k] you later.
What does Geoff have in the morning?
He only [k]has a coffee[/k] in the morning.
Let's chat! Describe a typical day. What time do you get up? What do you normally have for lunch? What do you usually do in the evenings?
When we talk about our routines and our free time, we can use different words to say how often things happen. We learned some of them earlier in the course.
Organise these words from least frequent to most frequent.
Let's now learn some longer and more interesting phrases that can also help us to say how often something happens.
once a day / twice a week / three times a month
I phone my dad every other day.
How often does Helen catch up with her boss?
They still get together for dinner every now and then.
This is similar in meaning to "sometimes".
It's only rained once or twice this month.
So we say "once a day" (lit: one time per day / X), "twice a day" (lit: two times per day / X), "three times a day", "four times a day", etc. Have a look at some more examples below.
How often does Mirco go on holiday?
Organise the phrases in meaning from the least frequent to the most frequent.
[k]four times a year[/k] [k]three times a month[/k] [k]twice a week[/k] [k]once a day[/k]
We still see each other every once in a while.
This is a synonym of "every now and then".
How often do they visit their friends?
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
We still see each other every [k]once[/k] in a while.
He has been late twice this month. It happens all the time.
This has the same meaning as "never".
This is similar in meaning to "always".
Match the beginning and the end of the sentences.
We have a catch up every
In a sentence, these phrases can usually go at the beginning or at the end.
Every other day, I phone my parents.
He makes breakfast every once in a while.
It's only rained once or [k]twice[/k] [k]this month[/k].
We put "all the time" at the end of the sentence.
He thinks about her all the time.
Select all the places (X) where "all the time " can go.
X He X is late to work [h]X[/h].
They meet for a chat every
Select all the places (X) where "all the time " can go.
[h]X[/h] We X go to my family party [h]X[/h].
Do you set your alarm [k]once a day[/k]?
Do you still catch up every once in a [k]w[/k][k]h[/k][k]i[/k][k]l[/k][k]e[/k]?
I walk my neighbour’s dog [k]every[/k] [k]other[/k] day.
She works from home [k]three times a week[/k]
We still go out for dinner [k]every now and then[/k].
Michael showers every day, in the morning and in the evening. Type a phrase that we've learned.
We see each other [k]every other weekend[/k].
Simon is often late to work. It always happens to him. Type the missing words.
It happens to me [k]all the time[/k].
